headline: Pairing AI with our brains: Precision Neuroscience's big bet
summary: Imagine being able to control a computer cursor with your mind. While it may sound like science fiction to many, major companies, like Meta (META) and Apple (AAPL) are investing in these technologies, and a handful of companies are working to make it a reality, including Precision Neuroscience. Co-founded by CEO Michael Mager and neurosurgeon and engineer Ben Rapoport, Precision Neuroscience began in 2021 with three former employees of Elon Musk’s Neuralink. Precision Neuroscience is developing its version of an implanted brain-computer interface (BCI) technology meant to help individuals with neurological disorders, such as ALS, to better function and communicate. Mager says Precision Neuroscience's technology is high-bandwidth, sits on "the surface of the brain without doing any damage," and is reversible.  In an interview with Yahoo Finance Senior Reporter Yasmin Khorram from the Yahoo Invest conference, Mager discusses the company's road ahead and potential market, what to expect from the upcoming Trump presidency, and a possible IPO. “We view brain computer interfaces as a generationally important life sciences innovation,” says Mager. “This is gonna have applicability today in paralysis, tomorrow in a number of different areas.” To see every interview from Yahoo Finance Invest, click here. This post was written by Luke Brooks.

headline: Meta Platforms Is Making AI Waves. ValueAct Bets $1 Billion.
summary: ValueAct Capital has amassed a $1 billion stake in Facebook and Instagram parent  Meta Platforms  a validation of the tech giant’s moves in artificial intelligence, a source familiar with the matter confirmed.  ValueAct, like other big money managers, is scheduled to release its quarterly investment disclosures later this week, but the filing will only reflect holdings as of the end of the third quarter.  ValueAct has engaged with the company, the source said, and the stake is seen as a long-term investment by the money manager.

ValueAct has engaged with the company, the source said, and the stake is seen as a long-term investment by the money manager.

headline: ValueAct takes $1-billion stake in Meta, source says
summary: (Reuters) -ValueAct Capital has built a $1-billion stake in Meta Platforms but is not currently pushing for big changes at the Facebook and Instagram parent, a source familiar with the matter told Reuters on Tuesday.  The stake, which ValueAct has been building in recent weeks, now ranks among the firm's two largest alongside its bet on cloud-based software company Salesforce.  Meta is worth $1.5 trillion and the company's stock price barely moved on the news, which was first reported by CNBC.

raw.headline: ValueAct takes $1-billion stake in Meta, source says
raw.summary: (Reuters) -ValueAct Capital has built a $1-billion stake in Meta Platforms but is not currently pushing for big changes at the Facebook and Instagram parent, a source familiar with the matter told Reuters on Tuesday.  The stake, which ValueAct has been building in recent weeks, now ranks among the firm's two largest alongside its bet on cloud-based software company Salesforce.  Meta is worth $1.5 trillion and the company's stock price barely moved on the news, which was first reported by CNBC.

headline: Facebook and Instagram users in Europe can opt for less personalized ads
summary: Facebook and Instagram users in Europe will get the option to see less personalized ads if they don't want to pay for an ad-free subscription, social media company Meta said Tuesday, bowing to pressure from Brussels over digital competition concerns.  Meta Platforms has been offering users in the European Union an ad-free subscription option for about a year to comply with the continent's strict data privacy rules, but regulators had accused the company of giving people a false choice.  The company said in a blog post that while people will still be able to choose between the subscription and free versions, it would also start giving users a third option over the coming weeks to see digital ads that are less personalized.

raw.headline: Facebook and Instagram users in Europe can opt for less personalized ads
raw.summary: Facebook and Instagram users in Europe will get the option to see less personalized ads if they don't want to pay for an ad-free subscription, social media company Meta said Tuesday, bowing to pressure from Brussels over digital competition concerns.  Meta Platforms has been offering users in the European Union an ad-free subscription option for about a year to comply with the continent's strict data privacy rules, but regulators had accused the company of giving people a false choice.  The company said in a blog post that while people will still be able to choose between the subscription and free versions, it would also start giving users a third option over the coming weeks to see digital ads that are less personalized.

headline: Meta to offer less personalized ads in Europe to appease regulators
summary: The Menlo Park, California-based company said it is implementing these changes in response to demands from EU regulators.  Over the coming weeks, people in the EU who use the company's social media platforms for free with ads, will be able to choose to see ads based on what Meta calls "context"- content that a user sees during a particular session on the platforms.  These ads will also target users based on age, gender, and location, with some being unskippable for a few seconds.

These ads will also target users based on age, gender, and location, with some being unskippable for a few seconds.
